statement:
In this entry, we shall compute the derivative of the exponential
function from its definition as a limit of powers.

If $0 \le x < 1$, then $$1 + x \le \exp x \le {1 \over 1-x}$$

By the inequalities for differences of powers, we have $$x \le 
\left( 1 + {x \over n} \right)^n - 1 \le 
{x \over 1 - \left( {n-1 \over n} \right) x} .$$ Since $n-1 < n$, and
$x > 0$, we have $0 < (n-1 / n) x < x$. Because $x < 1$, this implies
$1 - (n-1 / n) x > 1 - x$, so
$${x \over 1 - \left( {n-1 \over n} \right) x} <
{x \over 1 - x}.$$ Hence
$$1 + x \le \left( 1 + {x \over n} \right)^n \le {1 \over 1 - x}.$$
Taking the limit as $n \to \infty$, we obtain our result.

$$\lim_{x \to 0} {\exp (x) - 1 \over x} = 1$$

Assume $0 < x < 1$. By our bound, we have $$1 \le
{\exp (x) - 1 \over x} \le
{1 \over 1 - x} .$$ Suppose that $-1 < x < 0$. Then, since
$\exp (x) = 1 / \exp (-x)$, we have $${\exp (x) - 1 \over x} =
{1 \over \exp (-x)} \cdot {1 - \exp (-x) \over x} .$$ From the
inequality above, we have $$1 \le
{1 - \exp (-x) \over x} \le
{1 \over 1+x} .$$ Hence $${1 \over \exp (-x)} \le
{\exp (x) - 1 \over x} \le
{1 \over (1+x) \exp (-x)}.$$ By theorem 1, we have
$1 - x \le \exp (-x) \le 1 / (1 + x)$, so $$1+x \le
{1 - \exp (-x) \over x} \le
{1 \over (1 + x)(1-x)} =
{1 \over 1 - x^2} .$$ By the squeeze rule, we conclude that
$$\lim_{x \to 0} {1 - \exp (-x) \over x} = 1$$ whether we approach the
limit from the left or the right.

$${d \over dx} \exp (x) = \exp (x)$$

By definition, $${d \over dx} \exp (x) = 
\lim_{y \to x} {\exp (y) - \exp (x) \over y - x} .$$ By the addition
theorem for the exponential, we have
$${\exp (y) - \exp (x) \over y - x} =
\exp (x) \cdot {\exp (y-x) - 1 \over y - x} ,$$ so
$$\lim_{y \to x} {\exp (y) - \exp (x) \over y - x} =
\exp (x) \lim_{y \to x}
{\exp (y-x) - 1 \over y - x} =
\exp (x) \lim_{y \to 0} {\exp y - 1 \over y} .$$ By theorem 2, the limit
on the right-hand side equals $1$, so we have
$$\lim_{y \to x} {\exp (y) - \exp (x) \over y - x} = \exp (x) .$$
